summary: Background M. pneumoniae pneumonia (MP) has been reported in 10-40% of community-acquired pneumonia cases. a total of 191 children with MP were grouped by age: 2 years of age (29 patients), 3-5 years of age (81 patients), and 6 years of age (81 patients). in the most recent epidemics, the peak age was younger than that seen previously [6], but few studies have attempted a clinical comparison of MP according to age [4,5]. in some patients, the diagnostic antibodies are not detected in the early stage of M. pneumoniae infection [1]. a total of 1,083 patients with pneumonia or lower respiratory tract infections were admitted during this period. subjects were selected for inclusion in the study if seroconversion was shown on both assays during admission. patients who tested positive were excluded from the study. the chest radiographic findings were reviewed and classified independently by two pediatricians and one pediatric radiologist. we divided the 191 children with MP into three groups according to age. the bronchopneumonia group (25 patients), the mild segmental/lobar group (33 patients), and the severe segmental/lobar group (23 patients). median titers of MAA and cold agglutinins in seroconverters at discharge were 1:160 (range, 1:40-1:2,560) and 1:32 (range, 1:16-1:512) at discharge. no patient showed blood culture positive for bacterial pathogens including Streptococcus pneumoniae. the same 129 patients revealed that 2 patients were co-infected with respiratory viruses (respiratory syncytial virus and parainfluenza virus A) extrapulmonary manifestations of M. pneumoniae were observed as 19 cases of skin rash, 9 cases of abnormal hepatic enzymes (AST and ALT), and 1 case of encephalopathy. we observed significant differences in certain present study was between 9 months and 14 years, with peak incidence at 4-6 years of age. compared with younger children, older children had a more severe clinical course, manifested by longer total duration of fever, higher CRP, and a more severe pneumonia pattern. 45% of patients in the present study were seroconverters. absence of diagnostic IgM antibodies in the early stage of systemic infections has been well documented in previous studies of adults and children with MP. the detection of cold agglutinins (IgM) is nonspecific for M. pneumoniae infections. the titer of cold agglutinins in other systemic infections is rarely 1:64, except in M. pneumoniae infections. all children in this study were treated with amoxicillin with clavulanate and a macrolide (clarithromycin
